item.title: Microsoft Kinect Games Grocery Shopping at Texas Whole Foods | Wired Enterprise | Wired.com
item.description: Microsoft Kinect Games Grocery Shopping at Texas Whole Foods http://t.co/k8rlGOp2
item.content:encoded: Microsoft Kinect Games Grocery Shopping at Texas Whole Foods http://t.co/k8rlGOp2 The Board of Awesomeness is now lugging groceries at a Whole Foods in Texas. Last month, Chaotic Moon Lab's was one of the stars of the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. It's a motorized skateboard tricked up with a Samsung tablet and Microsoft's Kinect so that it can be steered by hand gestures and voice commands. But it turns that the Moon Lab had more on its mind than just skateboarding. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: wired.com

item.title: Mission Transition | Smashing UX Design
item.description: New on Smashing UX: Mission Transition - http://t.co/OdNhRkv8 (please RT)
item.content:encoded: New on Smashing UX: Mission Transition - http://t.co/OdNhRkv8 (please RT) When designing an application, an interface or any type of structured content, we must ensure that users understand where they have come from as they arrive at the new page or state. The transition from one screen or group of content to another should feel natural and should be tested on devices of varying power and speed to get a wider view of how the transition feels. Too fast, and it may appear broken or jumpy; too slow, and it will be frustrating to use. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: smashingmagazine.com

item.title: Transom » Jesse Thorn
item.description: On @Transom_org, I reveal my 12 POINT PROGRAM FOR ABSOLUTELY POSITIVELY 1000% GUARANTEED SUCCESS, aka MAKE YOUR THING http://t.co/qw2GWMrY
item.content:encoded: On @Transom_org, I reveal my 12 POINT PROGRAM FOR ABSOLUTELY POSITIVELY 1000% GUARANTEED SUCCESS, aka MAKE YOUR THING http://t.co/qw2GWMrY The commercial world guards its secrets. The game is competitive and money is the prize. The non-profit world, when it is functioning the way it should, upholds a spirit of generosity and common good. The two cultures tend not to mix very well, but Jesse Thorn ("The Sound of Young America," now "Bullseye") has brought to Transom a big-hearted and wise Manifesto in which he tells you how to make good things and, more surprisingly, how to make money at it. He could have kept the secrets to himself. Instead, he wrote "Make Your Thing: 12 Point Program for Absolutely, Positively 1000% No-Fail Guaranteed Success" with fascinating parables from comedy, hip-hop, blogging, cartooning and more. Jesse's own experience stretches across all sorts of independent media and performance. His words are practical and inspirational, and funny. They'll help you do better work. Jesse is donating his secrets in the best non-profit tradition. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: transom.org

item.title: The Green Benches: Another broken Tory Promise: e-petitions.
item.description: Tragic news: Despite receiving 162,000+ signatures, the Tories have blocked a petition to debate the NHS Bill http://t.co/zyKE5bIO
item.content:encoded: Tragic news: Despite receiving 162,000+ signatures, the Tories have blocked a petition to debate the NHS Bill http://t.co/zyKE5bIO (page 77 of the Tory Party's 2010 manifesto see here for confirmation) Given that 162,820+ citizens signed the petition to drop the NHS Bill (see here), why is it do you think that in the last hour the Backbench Business Committee has voted to block a debate in the House of Commons to Drop the NHS Bill? A Liberal Democrat MP who had the casting vote and joined with the Tories to ensure no debate took place. This is one of the very many reasons that this NHS Bill is the grossest violation of democracy the UK has suffered in more than 3 centuries. In Febraury 2010, David Cameron promised he would fix broken politics by guaranteeing any petition with 100,000 signatures a debate in the House of Commons. Sadly, he lied. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: eoin-clarke.blogspot.com

item.title: Trashing Tricare | Washington Free Beacon
item.description: This cannot stand! Trashing Tricare http://t.co/xNoTWb18 #militarymonday #tcot #gop @reincebrebius
item.content:encoded: This cannot stand! Trashing Tricare http://t.co/xNoTWb18 #militarymonday #tcot #gop @reincebrebius The Obama administration’s proposed defense budget calls for military families and retirees to pay sharply more for their healthcare, while leaving unionized civilian defense workers’ benefits untouched. The proposal is causing a major rift within the Pentagon, according to U.S. officials. Several congressional aides suggested the move is designed to increase the enrollment in Obamacare’s state-run insurance exchanges. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: freebeacon.com

item.title: » Is the IRS Attempting to Intimidate Local Tea Parties? - Big Government
item.description: Is the IRS Attempting to Intimidate Local Tea Parties?: In January and February of this year, the Internal Reve... http://t.co/UzrNcKCO
item.content:encoded: Is the IRS Attempting to Intimidate Local Tea Parties?: In January and February of this year, the Internal Reve... http://t.co/UzrNcKCO In January and February of this year, the Internal Revenue Service began sending out letters to various local Tea Parties across the country. Mailed from the same Cincinnati, Ohio IRS office, these letters have reached Tea Parties in Virginia, Hawaii, Ohio, and Texas (we are hearing of more daily). There are several common threads to these letters: all are requesting more information from these independent Tea Parties in regard to their nonprofit 501(c)(4) applications (for this type of nonprofit, donations are not deductible). While some of the requests are reasonable, much of them are strikingly onerous and, dare I say, Orwellian in nature. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: biggovernment.com

item.title: Amazon & Google Getting Impatient With Book Publishers
item.description: Amazon & Google Getting Impatient With Book Publishers http://t.co/Pc1SjoJD
item.content:encoded: Amazon & Google Getting Impatient With Book Publishers http://t.co/Pc1SjoJD All is not well in the e-book market. Amazon and Google have each scaled back some e-book programs in the past week because business was weaker than expected. Both e-book sellers are having trouble doing business with publishers. Amazon has pulled more than 4,000 books from its e-shelves after publishers wouldn't budge for lower prices. Google is cutting off partners in its e-book affiliates program because sales referrals are too low to be worthwhile.... Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: readwriteweb.com
